REVIEW_TITLE: Exquisitely Modern Gothic and A Welcoming Church
REVIEW_BODY: From afar the sight of the imposing tower and spire of the oldest Cathedral in Singapore will always capture one’s attention . We decided to attend the contemporary worship service 11:00 am Sunday. We were greeted by the sight of people congregating outside and inside the church , chatting , having lunch and just having fun. Inside the church a very solemn atmosphere greeted us . The ushers were very welcoming and we immediately felt part of this church . Truly amazing Christian love . ❤️

The St. Andrew's Cathedral is near the famous Padang and is quite centrally located. It is a quintessential cathedral and looks really beautiful. Its opposite to the Raffles City Mall, so accessibility is quite convenient.

Being one of the oldest churches in Singapore, it was founded back to over 100 years ago. This church has been significantly tied to the history of the development of Singapore. The building and furnishing made it worth to pay a visit.
Its a peaceful place but nothing impressive on the inside . Was crossing by so thought to just have a look

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place of worship in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: I went there for a Sunday evening service. The Church's architecture is refreshing. The Church compound has multiple activities going on for everyone. The service is full of praise and worship. It is a must visit while in Singapore. Its well connected on public transport.

REVIEW_TITLE: Visit an historic church in the city
REVIEW_BODY: A beautiful Anglican church built by convicts in the 1800s. Go in for a quiet time and admire the architecture.
In Singapore you find all religions. The church is beautifully crafted and very crowded on Sunday's . It's nice to visit and see from inside . Get good vibrations .

Unfortunately was not impressed with this place, we stopped by on our way to lunch and found it run down. The grounds look like they have not had their grass cut in years and the whole cathedral looks like it has seen better days. Difficult to also get into if you don’t see the entrance.

In Singapore, there are just a few "attractions" that are free...absolutely no admission charges!
If you would like to visit this beautiful, elegant and historic building, go to the Welcome Centre just next to the City Hall exit and ask for a free guided tour. You will be briefed on the history of Singapore and her link to this 150+ year-old cathedral, and you will be led to the various points of interest inside and around the building. And perhaps, you may be taken to one of the best-kept secret parts of the cathedral!

While walking along St Andrews (within SG's Civic District), the design of this church can easily get your attention especially if you like architecture / designs / old buildings and history/religious sites. This is the Cathedral church of Anglican Diocese of SG. The color (white) feels fresh, peaceful and pure. It is one of SG's National Monuments. It is walking distance from Bugis precinct, and just few walks from CityHall MRT.

The St.Andrew's is the biggest Cathedral in Singapore. It's in the very city center and makes an interesting contrast to the surrounding skyscrapers. It looks beautiful in a parks greenery shade with its whitewashed Gothic facade. However, the interior disappointed me, very simple.

This is the largest church in Singapore with breath taking stained glass panels. The high ceilings are reminscent of the gothic cathedrals that one sees in countries like England. Great photo opportunities.

REVIEW_TITLE: Very tranquil spot right in the center of it all
REVIEW_BODY:
We went over to St Andrew's Cathedral during the Christmas break.

There was a special Christmas fair on at the time.

There were a lot of activities for children and an interesting one that inculcated the values of Christmas via a game.

The grounds are fairly well maintained and were nice to walk around in.

A nice place to get away from it all.
The cathedral is white walled and unfussy in design but still possesses a photogenic spire and interior. It is a nice cool retreat from the hot and humid Singapore climate.
Lovely cathedral and a really wonderful remembrance service. I will remember this as the highlight of my trip.

Made a visit to St Andrew’s Cathedral in Singapore City whilst visiting, the Cathedral has a lot of British history attached to it as it served as a field hospital during the Second World War. There are several plaques remembering the various regiments that fought the Japanese in what was a very cruel and hard fought war.

The Cathedral is a landmark really worthwhile visiting whilst in Singapore.

Very enjoyable and peaceful Cathedral.
A beautiful cathedral in the heart of the city. Showing it’s age, but stunning inside and out, worth the stop even for 10 minutes to take it in

This quintessentially English building in the heart of Singapore lends an ineffable aura of history to the heart of the Island state. it is well worth a visit and conjures up visions of Edwardian straw boaters and all the faded pageantry of Empire.

This is a very nice church built in the Gothic style. We visited on a Sunday morning and ended up staying for part in the service when we were handed bulletins by some very friendly parishioners.

The interior is simple yet beautiful in blue and white.
Popped in to sit and reflect. Very peaceful interior albeit lots of hubbub from visitors outside. Large and calm Cathedral

An oasis in a busy city to see the Christian faith worked out in practice. A quiet and contemplative space for ALL who want somewhere to rest. Much to see and look at . The posters about the personnel in World War 2 were thought provoking!
The largest church in singapore and built in 1856. There are trees right in front of the church making phototaking for tourists hilarious
This cathedral is the oldest Anglican house of worship in the country. The stained glass windows are really something to see. It is painted white and at night is it absolutely outstanding.

REVIEW_TITLE: Oasis of Peace in a Busy City.
REVIEW_BODY:
The imposing tower and spire of the Cathedral makes it a stand-out landmark in the Civic District. It is Singapore’s largest cathedral and the oldest Anglican house of worship in the country. The building dates to 1856 and was gazette a National Monument in 1973. The stained glass windows are just some of the many features highlighting colonial history. The structure is painted white and stands in a rather extensive garden setting surrounded by the bustle of the City. The Cathedral New Sanctuary is easy to overlook, it is largely built underground.
Take a seat in a pew and enjoy your surroundings or take a few minutes to reflect on life.

St Andrew’s Cathedral is the oldest church in Singapore located in Civil District near City Hall MRT station. Beautiful architecture, big courtyard with tress and multi colored glass windows. This place of worship is filled with objects & pictures that represents its history.
Visiting hours Mon-Sun 9 am - 5 pm
For free guided tours approach visitors center within the church premises.

Very near to the Museums & not far from Raffles, worth a visit and the people here extremely friendly they were getting ready for a big Wedding and were busy decorating the Church it looked beautiful against the white backdrop.

We are only in Singapore for a couple of days and spent some of our precious time here attending worship this morning. According to their website the Cathedral is ‘a busy church but we will always try and make you welcome’. We didn’t feel welcome at all. We attend church every week (I’m an ordained Christian minister in the UK) found the worship to be very standard - not particularly inspiring. My husband has coeliac disease so asked about gluten free wafers for communion - no one seemed to have heard of gluten free so he couldn’t take communion. One reason we wanted to go was to see the Coventry Cathedral cross of nails - an amazing symbol of hope and reconciliation - it’s hidden in the pulpit and no one but the preacher is allowed near it - what a shame - the story of the Cross of Nails and the movement for peace and reconciliation should be told not hidden away. My husband stood on the pulpit steps to try and take a photo (there was nothing to say he shouldn’t) and he was told very rudely that he shouldn’t have stood on the steps and a chain (not there before was placed across. When we asked about seeing the cross we were told that we couldn’t. Even when I explained a link between my late father and Coventry and also between him and Singapore we were still not allowed to see the cross. Apart from this encounter no one spoke to us (apart from the person who’d led the service saying goodbye on the way out) Very sad - I certainly wouldn’t go back. Fortunately our day was redeemed by the very helpful welcome we received an hour later at the botanical gardens which are stunningly beautiful. God felt more present there than in the church

Access is gained though a side entrance and not through the main doors. We always try to light a candle for our grandson who is no longer with us, but sadly this facility wasn't available to us. However we did spend some time in quiet reflection in this beautiful church.

REVIEW_TITLE: At the centre of the colonial area
REVIEW_BODY:
A pleasant oasis very much in the heart of the colonial district. Quite plain inside but functional for the climate, and full of interesting artefacts and memorials.

Adjacent to numerous bus routes on North Bridge Road so easy to hop on a bus when your visit is over.
This great place of peace and tranquillity has not changed over the years. This is still a very welcoming place to pray and enjoy the feeling of peace.

If you are visiting Singapore on a Sunday, a visit to St Andrews Cathedral is a must to attend one of the seven services, so there is no excuse. The Cathedral is beautifully looked after and everyone is so helpful and polite. A truly wonderful place to visit, and it's good to see it hasn't changed since I worked in Singapore during 1971/2. During the week the Cathedral is always open and a visit is truly recommended

This cathedral is built in 1861 and it is located nearby City Hall MRT, thus many people would pass by this building. The cathedral exterior is colonial style and the interior is serene and full of tinted glass. The mass has ended when we are there but it is open to public for praying. Love the environment a lot and though there are many tourists around, the place is quiet. There are many people taking photos outside, highly recommended to come as the architecture is quite different from the Western as it corporate the multi culture of our local island into this cathedral.

REVIEW_TITLE: Peaceful, charming and with a reverent atmosphere
REVIEW_BODY:
Anglican Cathedral set (now) amongst the shopping malls , and offices of Singapore's CBD, and being built in 1836 , really reflects the architecture and norms of that Colonial period. Happily, some of the now held there are multi- lingual, and proudly reflect the heritage of many parishioners.
Outside, apart from the the snow white paint features, this place would not look out of place in southern England. Inside, it is the same impressive story, with stained glass, high vaulted ceilings and a long nave give this lovely building prestige.
Lovely building, happily still in its own grounds ( despite the sky high price of potential building land). Peaceful, charming and with a reverent atmosphere.

This impressive white-faced building overlooks the Padang. The Foundation Stone dates from 1834 and, like most other buildings of the period was on the site chosen by Sir Stamford Raffles. The current building was consecrated in 1862 by the Bishop of Calcutta and remains a most welcoming church to Christians for worship and tourists for interest….and it IS interesting.

There are informative guide pamphlets available in many languages and some beautiful stained glass and stone architecture. It is easily accessible from the MRT, located close to the City Hall station, cricket ground and an easy stroll down to the river and the Merlion.

This is an Anglican Cathedral and the oldest in Singapore. The cathedral conducts services in various languages, which is in keeping with the Singaporean philosophy to multi-cultural respect. This snow white building with its towering spire is visible from many locations around the city. Sadly the nave was closed for renovations, but a peek through the windows and the front doors showed a beautiful and peaceful place to worship.
Very beautiful building from the outside and very different to most buildings in the city. Unfortunately closed when we tried to visit but looked fantastic.
This very modern cathedral does not have much character, except the organ looks older. If you are passing, worth popping in, but just for a look.

This is hardly a cathedral and better from the outside. Not spiritual, very noisy with leaf blowers and builders, not beautiful at all. Full of noisy Chattering locals .don't bother going in . There are so many amazing cathedrals to be seen in England and abroad .
Disappointing.

We needed to get out of the Singapore heat and humidity. A placard invited us to the St Andrew’s Cathedral café.

The café occupies a large space. Its air conditioned, modernised and nicely painted. It’s so peaceful. The staff are plentiful, very friendly and helpful. And, the coffee was actually very good. A great place for a cool coffee fix.

The cathedral, located in the middle of a rather large park, looks absolutely beautiful from the outside. However, trying to enter it during its supposed opening time was futile. So instead, we admired the place's exteriors, which were lovely.

A historic church in the heart of Singapore, built by convicts during the British colonial days of old. It is beautiful, stately and majestic, sited in the prime central district. Today a huge underground train station is to be found beneath the church. It is a busy Anglician church that has always been in use ,unlike many overseas that had been abandoned by parishioners.

We were lucky enough to attend a Sunday service (one of about 10 that day). We were made VERY welcome. The singing was great, the organ was tremendous, the fellowship was overwhelming. A true place of God on earth.

Having arrived early in Singapore early in the day before our hotel room was ready we left our bags with the concierge and went off to explore the surrounding area.

Only a short distance from the hotel we came across St. Andrews Cathedral.

It is a beautifully maintained building that provides a focal point for many who not only visit as tourists but locals who clearly make full use of the Cathedral and all of its facilities.

Take a look at the stained glass windows and if a sunny day as when we visited look at the patterns projected as the sun shines through.

The open windows provide a great view across the grounds to the cricket ground just a short distance away from where from time to time you can hear the sound of willow striking the ball.

The collection of hymn and prayer books is as impressive as any I've see anywhere reflecting the diversity of those who attend.

The grounds are immaculately kept and well used.

We on our first downtown adventure and knew this was in the area. Not difficult to find. It isn't bolstered by gilded stuff. It is a simple wonderful community church that happens to be a Cathedral. The prayer books are in about 5-6 languages. There is a sign posted inside the door if you need someone to talk to or pray with there are contact numbers available. Walking the walk there is also a chapel for all people on the grounds. Loved it!

If you are visiting Singapore on a Sunday, a visit to St Andrews Cathedral is a must to attend one of the seven services, so there is no excuse. The Cathedral is beautifully looked after and everyone is so helpful and polite. A truly wonderful place to visit, and it's good to see it hasn't changed since I worked in Singapore during 1971/2
Pretty average cathedral as they go - I got married in a much fancier one! However nice and peaceful, cool and quiet and seeing it against the juxtaposition of the skyscrappers makes it stand out.

This sparkling white cathedral is situated near City Hall overlooking a rugby ground. It is surrounded by modern high rise. We went to a Sunday morning service which had a large attendance but still managed to feel fairly intimate.
Worth a visit for a service or just to appreciate the peace and tranquillity of the place.

Definitely not the most impressive church in the world, but really stands out amid all the skyscrapers and modern buildings. Upon arrival it seems that the church was actually closed. In fact the main entrance is closed and you have to enter via the marquee which is at the car park side of the church. It is still a functioning church so you may find people inside praying, so as in any religious building, it is best to remain as silent as possible. Photos can be taken inside without a problem. Would make this part of a general sightseeing tour of the area, not really worth making it a specific "must see".

REVIEW_TITLE: worth a pic when walking past
REVIEW_BODY: didn't go inside but church looked nice from outside. took a quick pic on way to merlion from hotel. was on walking trail that took in historic places

This is one of the most iconic religious building in Singapore and it is still in service. Both the interior and exterior are beautiful and it's easily reachable by MRT (City Hall) and also buses as it is located in the city centre.

This place is lovely to look at both from the outside and inside. Walk around and look at the memorial places. There are also services which you can attend. Outside there is a lovely park, which on a Sunday many people come to enjoy and meet up.
We visited the Cathedral recently. Beautifully designed Cathedral. Located right in the centre of the city, just outside the City Hall MRT. Quite a big campus, considering the central location.

REVIEW_TITLE: quite church in the middle of the city
REVIEW_BODY: we went there to check out this church, there was no mass during that time and most of the people who went there were just taking pictures. the seats near the center aisle are divided individually and have arm rests. they have singaporean and english bibles/hyms/mass guides on the back of the chairs.
A very pleasant building in the heart of the city and in contrast to a lot of the city. A place of worship.

Most people come across the cathedral as they walk by. Its well used by the locals. So if you want to see a good community church and not a tourist ruin this is worth a visit. Nothing spectacular about it, just a very pleasant escape from the heat and noise for some nice contemplation of the soul.

REVIEW_TITLE: Busy and clearly part of the community
REVIEW_BODY: Our fist attempt to visit was unsuccessful as the nave was closed for repairs. Went back the next day and the first thing we noticed was how busy the environs were with community activities. The church itself was quite full of people sitting in contemplation. It's not a huge cathedral but lovely and light.

Situated in the centre of Singapore, standing on a grassed lawn the church, built in the 1800's, stands out from the modern skyscrapers and is a constant reminder of the colonisation of Singapore. Whilst not as grandiose as European churches, it is still beautiful in its unique way and standing inside it's easy to be transported back to the time of Raffles and you can imagine them sitting here, dressed to the hilt, in 40 degree heat. It's free to drop in and on the way to many places so have a look.

REVIEW_TITLE: The strangest church I have ever visited.
REVIEW_BODY: From outside, the cathedral is very beautiful. Inside things get weird. There was some kind of café, vending machines and the church itself was stuffed with fans, air conditioners and tv screens. Decorations and ornaments are very simple.

No lover of cathedrals can visit Singapore without visiting St Andrew's. Set in its own city block and surrounded by trees, it stands out as a white beacon. In fact, the exterior with its many towers and expansive transepts is probably more impressive than the interior. Coming inside, it is a surprise that the transepts make no appearance in the worship space. However the sanctuary area is very pleasant, and I enjoy the West window of the Four Evangelists. I understand that this cathedral goes back to the early beginnings of Singapore.

In terms of Cathedral's this one is not all that big. We went on a Sunday and were able to peek a look inside during worship - and it was not as impressive as I had been led to believe. The grounds around are also in need of some maintenance.
This white Cathedral stands out in the jungle of glass and stone and is very peaceful for the visitors. It is a nice escape from the heat.

In the very popular shopping area, you can experience a peaceful and spiritual moment in such a beautiful historical church is precious thing. Of course, the interior decoration not so grand as the church you find in Germany or Spain. The more I like is the park around the church. Lots of people have picnic on the grassland. So free and charming.

REVIEW_TITLE: Awesome and peaceful place in the heart of Singapore city
REVIEW_BODY: Attended a Sunday 11.15 service in the cathedral, it was quite an experience. Must have been more than 500 at the service. Other services were also being held at same time in more venues within the grounds, it was such a vibrant place and a must go if your here, check out their website for more details and daily events.

You can't miss this large whitewashed church in the middle of Singapore. Getting into it is another thing! We wandered round the large lawned gardens to the main entrance which was closed. We eventually found a side entrance where maintenance work was being carried out but managed to get inside. Quite a plain building inside but lovely for a bit of quiet time in a busy city. Free entrance.

It was pouring rain the day we visited and most entrances were closed off so we only took pix of the beautiful whitewashed exterior with its twin spires. Impressive to look at and grounds were nicely maintained.

REVIEW_TITLE: Sanctuary in the midst of a bustling city
REVIEW_BODY: Not large or grand by European’s standard, the national monument stood at the crossroads of Singapore and witness many a historical moments of Singapore’s history since its inception in 1861. Visitors are welcome to take a break at the cafe or sit in the silent hall of the Nave to reflect and pray. Service are open to visitors of from all creeds and races.

The cathedral is a short walk from City Hall MRT Station / Raffles City Shopping Center.

It is a old Anglican Church, with most worship services on weekends. Quite a number of tourists come here to see the large service halls with its tall ceilings and stained glass murals, wooden pews and the procession after each service. On church grounds are also vast areas of empty grass where you will see many tourists and domestic/foreign workers come spend their weekend leisurely catching up with friends.

REVIEW_TITLE: It is the largest cathedral in the country.
REVIEW_BODY:
Cathedral for the Anglican Diocese in Singapore, the largest cathedral in the country.
The original version of the church of St. Andrew was built in 1835-1836, respectively. She, like the second version of the church, were destroyed. The modern cathedral was built in the neo-Gothic architectural style in 1861 and consecrated on January 25, 1862. Although the cathedral is Anglican, it is dedicated to the patron saint of Scotland, since it was built with donations from Scottish merchants.

I love architecture, so of course this was a place for me. A magnificent man made structure dedicated to worship. When I was there, there was a service on and I found it moving, uplifting and spiritual; I am not normally moved this way, I left feeling I was just in a special place.

The Cathedral is open and welcoming to anyone, there is no charge, so just pay respect no matter your beliefs.

Set yourself a walk around Singapore and this is a must visit.

St. Andrew's Cathedral is Singapore's largest cathedral. It is near City Hall and it is an Anglican cathedral. It is Gothic style and is an example of colonial-era architecture and heritage. The structure is 68.58 m long and 35.5 m wide.

St Andrews Cathedral is centrally located in Singapore city not far from Raffles City Mall. It is an Anglican cathedral and the largest in Singapore. It was opened over one hundred and fifty years ago.

The setting is in lovely manicured lawns. It is painted white - and at night the cathedral is lit up and looks truly magnificent. Inside the cathedral,

Services are held in different languages in the old sanctuary and the new sanctuary in the basements.

Inside the cathedral, there are beautiful stained windows.

There is limited parking in the cathedral grounds.

This is a lovely white building with an interior of blue and white, with stained glass windows. It is a very large cathedral, and I was told it was the largest Anglican cathedral in Asia. There are large lawns surrounding the building, and I saw a bridal couple posing for photographs on the lawn with the Cathedral in the background. When I went into the Cathedral I was handed some postcards depicting the Cathedral, and a little pamphlet about it. I was not there for a service, but simply sat on one of the seats for a short period of meditation.
This church is close raffles park mrt and is beautiful illuminated at night,good to see if you walking around here

St. Andrews is set off by itself in the middle of town. Right by MRT station NS25, City Hall.
Surrounded by lots of other tourist sites, it's worth the 20 minutes to go and have a look.
It's not as highly ornate as some Cathedrals are, but the design is appealing.
Worth a quick visit.

I was on my way to the Merlion Park and came across this beautiful cathedral. Unfortunately a service was in session so I was not allowed to visit the inside. From the outside, it is majestic! Good for pictures in a sunny day!

Recommend time to spend - 10-15 minutes for a quick visit and prayer!

Overall, it's not super impressive on the inside, but it is free and calm and really quite pretty. There's no air conditioning in the main church, but there are fans, so it can be a nice break to sit for a while and contemplate.
It's between City Hall subway station and National Gallery of Singapore whick is in old supreme Court building. It's a beautiful church, they have parking and even a cafe. The building is beautiful.

Went and couldn't find an entrance or anything it all appeared closed off! Sat outside on the bench and looked at it - not sure if there are set times when it's open but I went during the day on a weekday!

REVIEW_TITLE: Quiet and peaceful sanctuary in the bustling city
REVIEW_BODY:
Quiet place to sit down and have a rest while admiring the architecture. Good escape from the noisy and bustling environment of the city outside. Great for photos and abit of history.

Staff are friendly to visitors and would give short tours of the place.

The entrance to the Cathedral is located next to the City Hall MRT station and across the road from Raffles City (Shopping Center) which is a great place for shopping and food. Another great place for photos is Capitol Theater which is also across the road from the church, the neon Capitol Theater sign lights up nicely at night.
This church is situated right in the center of action, surrounded by malls and hotels. Old and beautiful church and visitors can simply walk in to enjoy the tranquility this place has to offer.
A beautiful place. Stop by at any time of the day. You will experience a sense of peace. And the cathedral does make for good pictures.
This review is quite late. During one of my trips to Singapore I had the opportunity to hear mass at St. Andrew's Cathedral which attracts a huge crowd of Catholic devotees.

My father was posted to Sigapore in the eary 50s whilst in the RAF. I visited the cathedral because I'm sure he would have attended. It was a moment of reminiscence for me while I read/hummed his favourite hymn and thought of younger days. So glad to have easy access. My thanks to St Andrew's.

Physical churches where established for people of God to worship. I was fortunate to visit the Singapore’s most famous church. I was awed by the grandeur and elegant facade of the church. The simplicity of the interior made me pray and kneel before God. Thank you was not enough considering that this was my second time to visit Singapore. Singapore made me realized that the world is not only Philippines; that there was a bigger arena for me to explore and wander. My trip to another country would not be complete if I will not visit a church. I felt at peace and guided when I was able to visit a church. Life is too short that one must attached himself to his Creator; that living is not only for oneself but importantly, for the love of mankind especially the needy and less fortunate. Indeed, traveling enabled me to view world in a dynamic perspective and that life is not a solitary thing.

The St. Andrews Cathedral is more of a church than a cathedral in my estimation. Do not expect grandeur; it is a simple space to contemplate. The outside is more impressive than the interior. It is right next to the City Hall MRT.
A beautiful and well-kept cathedral, excellent grounds. Unfortunately it was closed - preparations for some event were underway - but overall impression was very good.

I had totally missed this striking church on previous visit to Singapore. Impressive interior and exterior color. Extremely quiet. Probably should be rating this a 5. Very easy to visit. Hard to miss if you are on foot.

REVIEW_TITLE: Disappointing to me, compared to other Houses of Worship in Singapore and with Cathedrals in other cities
REVIEW_BODY:
I usually love seeing the cathedrals in every city I travel to. So, I sought this cathedral out during a recent Singapore visit.

During this trip, I saw many other Chinese temples and Indian places of worship also, I loved them all. This places, to me, pales in comparison to any of them. Not much going on, not very many people just at the place that worship there.

A cool exterior in a huge open space, inside was disappointing to me as it was a basic cathedral with simple decoration and stained glass. None of the ornateness of other Cathedrals anywhere, even in small towns in Italy for example.

There is a Metro Stop (City Hall) at the Cathedral. So easy to get to.

Not worth making a special visit to see, no sense of pride of the place by the people that work there/go there to worship.

The place was interestingly white against the background of Singapore as a whole. It was also closed when I went. So I didn't get to see the inside, but it was still worth looking at from the outside.
A must see nice and quiet. It’s free nice old church. Some interesting plaques and headstone mounted on wall. Well worth a visit and be respectful people are praying.
It is located in the center of the colonial part of Singapore. Built more than 150 years ago in early Gothic style. The cathedral is relatively small, but it is worth visiting.Anglican cathedral

REVIEW_TITLE: Charming but doesn't compare with European cathedrals
REVIEW_BODY: We love visiting churches, but when you've been to the amazing cathedrals in Europe this doesn't really cut it. Even so, worth visiting as part of the colonial history of Singapore.

We attended a Cambridge choir Christmas performance at this church and were most impressed with it's quiet elegance and beauty, excellent and warm organisation and hospitality shown to seat and accommodate the large crowd who turned up for the lunch performance. The church grounds were significant considering this is right in the centre of the city. Noticed that they gave direct access to the church grounds for those coming by MRT, the underground. And there was a bright and cheerful cafe at the MRT station, for a nice cuppa, with interesting reading materials. Was informed that this church runs a very good Sunday School for all who wish to attend.

St Andrew's Cathedral, once a prominent landmark in central Singapore City, is now dwarfed by the surrounding skyscrapers of Singapore's financial district.

But its all-white exterior catches your attention as you drive or walk past on St Andrews Road.

The original St Andrew's Church was built in 1835 and the second was built in 1842.

It was demolished in 1855 after two lightening strikes and rumours of evil spirits and devils spiting the church.

The new foundation stone was laid in 1856 and the first service was in 1861.

Today St Andrew's Cathedral is the focal point of the Anglican community in Singapore.

It is open to the public, and even if you are not a Christian, it is worth visiting, sitting in a pew, and quietly contemplating how peaceful it is inside compared the the hustle and bustle of outside modern Singapore City.

This cathedral is symbolic of the British Colonial era built in 1856, and is the place of worship of the Diocese of Singapore - part of the Anglican Church. It is easily reached from City Hall MRT - from which it is just a one minute walk. It boasts very nice stained glass. one of the windows bears the arms of the diocese and its adjacent window that of The Province of South East Asia. The church has numerous plaques to its colonial period. It is a cool and tranquil oasis and is nice to sit a while. It is a nice place to wander.

Leonard Wilson was Bishop of Singapore, when Singapore fell in 1942. He was an enormously gifted man and never failed in his belief - for which the Japanese imprisoned him. He came back to eventually be the Bishop of Birmingham after the war - its worth Googling him, and also if you visit the Changi Prison Museum, you will see more of him there.

It is worth a visit to Equinox Bar at the Swiss Hotel for a great aerial view of the cathedral.

REVIEW_TITLE: Gorgeous old church in heritage style
REVIEW_BODY: Happened across this beautiful church in the heart of the city. Magnificent stain glassed windows, polished timber pews and fans oscillating to cool down church goers. Many locals were picnicking outside on little mats giving the place a lovely community feeling about it. Very picturesque.

Located just beside City Hall MRT. St Andrew's has very nice architecture and we saw two couples taking wedding photos. Take some time to visit the interior as it is just as beautiful inside. We spent some time inside just feeling relaxed and basking in the peacefulness.
This is small church in the middle of big building.A pretty church.Not many people around looks a bit neglected.The architecture is good.

REVIEW_TITLE: An OK Cathedral ... I did like some of the wood lattice work which was surprising to find in such a tropical climate!
REVIEW_BODY: An OK Cathedral ... I did like some of the wood lattice work which was surprising to find in such a tropical climate! Really cool old school personal seats are a great place to rest and admire the rest of the Cathedral from!!
